questions.text: Identify the type of lens in this picture:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigid Gas Permeable Lens

 

Option B:

 

  • Oxygen-permeable or rigid gas-permeable lenses are made of a firm, durable plastic that transmits oxygen.
  • Materials used include copolymer of PMMA and silicone and cellulose acetate butyrate.
  • As they do not contain water, they resist deposits and are less likely than soft contact lenses to harbor bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Soft Contact Lens: Made of soft, flexible plastics that allow oxygen to pass through to the cornea, soft contact lenses are comfortable and easier to adapt to than rigid lenses.

 

Option C. Hard Contact Lens: Made of a rigid, durable plastic, hard contact lenses are less comfortable and less oxygen-permeable compared to soft or rigid gas permeable lenses and are rarely used today.

 

Option D. Scleral Contact Lens: Large-diameter lenses that vault over the entire corneal surface and rest on the sclera, scleral lenses are used for specific corneal irregularities and provide comfort for sensitive eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid Gas Permeable Lens: are more durable than soft contact lenses, provide clearer vision, and are breathable, allowing more oxygen to reach the cornea.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 82

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurring of vision since the past few months. During evaluation, she is subjected to retinoscopic refraction wherein the streak of light and the shadow moved in opposite directions. Based on this, what is the refractive error she is likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myopia >1D.

 

Option D:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypermetropia > 1D: Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, is indicated by "with motion" in retinoscopy (where the light streak and shadow move in the same direction), not "against motion".

 

Option B. Myopia < 1D: Produces with movement.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia < 1D: Similar to option A, hypermetropia would not present with "with motion" in retinoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinoscopy, if the streak of light and the shadow move in opposite directions (against motion), it typically indicates myopia, and the speed of the shadow's movement can help determine the degree of myopia. A quick shadow movement against the light streak suggests myopia greater than 1 diopter.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 59

questions.text: ​​​​​In a child undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is added to the irrigating solution to prevent postoperative inflammatory membrane formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heparin         

 

Option C: The role of infusion fluid during cataract surgery:

 

  1. To aid in the smooth removal of the lens and
  2. Restore the aqueous humor at the end of the procedure.

 

Additives to Infusion Fluid:

 

  1. Preservative-Free Antibiotics – Prophylaxis
  2. Adrenaline 0.3ml of 1:1000 in 500ml – to maintain Mydriasis.
  3. Preservative free Low Molecular Weight Heparin 10 IU/ml – prevent postoperative severe fibrinous inflammatory membrane formation in children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adrenaline (Epinephrine) is often added to local anesthetic solutions to constrict blood vessels, thereby reducing bleeding and prolonging the duration of anesthesia. While it may help in maintaining pupil dilation during surgery, it is not primarily used for controlling postoperative inflammation.

 

Option B. Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes dilation of the pupil and paralysis of accommodation. It is not typically used in the irrigating solution during cataract surgery, and its primary role is not in controlling postoperative inflammation.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. While it is commonly used in ophthalmology for controlling inflammation, it is typically administered as an eye drop or injection, not in the irrigating solution during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparin is added to the irrigating solution during pediatric cataract surgery to prevent the formation of postoperative inflammatory membranes.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 158

choices.text: Increase in latency only
Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude
Decrease in latency and increase in amplitude

questions.text: VEP in optic neuropathy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude

 

Option C:

 

  • Visual evoked potential (VEP) tests record electrical activity of the visual cortex created by retinal stimulation.
  • The most common indications in ophthalmology are the monitoring of visual function in babies and the investigation of optic neuropathy.
  • Interpretation - Latency and amplitude are assessed.
  • In optic neuropathy both parameters are affected, with prolongation of latency and decrease in amplitude.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase in Latency Only:

 

  • Latency refers to the time it takes for a signal to travel from the eye to the visual cortex in the brain.
  • An increase in latency means the signal is slower than normal, which can happen in optic neuropathy due to demyelination or other nerve damage.
  • However, this option does not consider changes in amplitude, which are also important in the context of optic nerve damage.

 

Option B. Increase in Amplitude Only:

 

  • Amplitude in VEP represents the strength or intensity of the signal reaching the visual cortex.
  • An increase in amplitude is not typically associated with optic neuropathy. In fact, optic nerve damage more commonly leads to a decrease in amplitude due to reduced signal transmission efficiency.

 

Option D. Decrease in Latency and Increase in Amplitude:

 

  • A decrease in latency would imply faster-than-normal signal transmission, which is not characteristic of optic neuropathy.
  • Similarly, an increase in amplitude is not typical of optic neuropathy, where signal strength usually diminishes.
  • This pattern is contrary to what is expected in optic nerve damage and is not a typical finding in optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that in optic neuropathy, Visual Evoked Potentials typically show an increase in latency and a decrease in amplitude, reflecting delayed and weakened transmission of visual signals due to optic nerve damage.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 751

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Vogt's triad following an episode of acute primary angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Goniosynechiae

 

Option D.

 

  • Goniosynechiae refer to iridiotrabecular adhesions of the peripheral iris to the trabecular meshwork. It is not a part of Vogt’s triad.

 

 

  • Vogt’s triad is seen in both treated and untreated cases after an attack of acute PAC glaucoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glaucomflecken (Anterior Subcapsular Lenticular Opacity). These are the small, white, opaque spots on the lens indicative of previous acute attacks.

 

 

Option B. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy.

 

Option C. Patches of iris atrophy occurs due to ischemia from the prolonged contact between the iris and the trabecular meshwork.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of Vogt's triad for primary angle closure glaucoma include glaukomflecken, iris atrophy, and mid-dilated pupil.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th edition, page 245

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral loss of vision with normal pupillary light reflex. Ocular evaluation was found to be normal. VEP shows extinguished response. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cortical blindness

 

Option B:

 

  • The given features are suggestive of cortical blindness.
  • It is total or partial loss of vision in normal appearing eye caused by damage to brain’s occipital cortex.
  • It most commonly results from ischemia due to blockade of posterior cerebral artery.
  • Macular sparing is present in occipital lobe lesions.
  • Pupillary reactions and fundoscopy are normal.
  • Visual evoked response (VER) examination shows extinguished responses .
  • ANTON SYNDROME – denial of blindness by patients who can’t see (lack of insight).
  • RIDDOCH PHENOMENON – ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Malingering: wilful ‘blind’ behaviour, i.e. feigning of symptoms. On clinical examination, no ocular or neuro-ophthalmic findings are detectable which can account for the symptoms. Multiple tests like Prism test, Worth four-dot test are devised to diagnose this condition.

 

Option C. Retrobulbar neuritis: Definitive or relative afferent pupillary defect would be present.

 

Option D. Hysterical blindness: Unlike malingering, there is little or no insight into their infirmity in these cases and may sometimes display a complete lack of concern over their incapacitating symptoms (la belle indifference). May be associated with blepharospasm and lacrimation. Visual fields are concentrically contracted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical blindness is characterized by an inability to see despite normal eyes and pupillary reflexes. The disrupted cortical processing is evidenced by extinguished VEPs.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no:328

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive vision loss in both eyes over the past few months. Upon examination, a swollen, bulging lens with increased lens thickness is observed. The diagnosis of intumescent cataract is made. What is the diameter of a normal adult crystalline lens?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 9 – 11 mm

 

Explanation:

 

Diameter of the lens:

 

  • At Birth            = 6.5 mm
  • Adult                = 9 to 11 mm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diameter if normal crystalline lens is 9-11 mm.

 

Ref: Pg 110/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Extended Depth of Focus IOL.

questions.text: Which of the following IOLs is used to correct both distant & near vision?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IOLs used for correcting both distant & near vision together include:

 

  • Trifocal iols
  • Bifocal IOLs or Multifocal IOLs
  • Diffractive iols
  • Accommodative IOLs
  • Extended Depth of Focus IOL.

 

Ref:  Pg 310/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Structures derived from Surface Ectoderm:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The surface ectoderm gives rise to crystalline lens, epithelium of cornea and epithelium of conjunctiva.

 

 

Ref: Pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which of the following types of amblyopia is associated with worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulus deprivation amblyopia

 

Option C:

 

  • The least common, most severe and difficult to treat, is visual deprivation amblyopia (also known as stimulus deprivation amblyopia).
  • This is due to an eye abnormality that obstructs the visual axis or otherwise interferes with central vision.

 

CAUSES:

 

  1. Congenital or early-acquired cataract
  2. Blepharoptosis
  3. Periocular lesions obstructing the visual axis
  4. Corneal opacities
  5. Vitreous haemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anisometropic Amblyopia: This results from unequal refractive errors in the two eyes. Its prognosis is generally good with appropriate corrective lenses and amblyopia therapy, especially if treated early.

 

Option B. Strabismic Amblyopia: Caused by misalignment of the eyes (strabismus), this type of amblyopia has a variable prognosis depending on the severity and treatment of the strabismus.

 

Option D. Meridional Amblyopia: Associated with uncorrected astigmatism, this type of amblyopia has a generally good prognosis with appropriate corrective lenses and amblyopia therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stimulus deprivation amblyopia has the worst prognosis among the types of amblyopia listed, due to the profound impact of visual deprivation during the critical developmental period of the visual system.

 

Ref: AAO PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS PAGE 55

questions.text: A Myopic patient was posted for Radial Keratotomy. What is the size of the optical zone left while making Peripheral Corneal Incisions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Radial Keratotomy is one of the Surgical Procedures done for correction of Myopia.
  • It is a type of Refractive Keratoplasty which is done to Modify the Refractive Power of the Cornea.
  • In this, Multiple Radial Incisions are made in the periphery of the cornea leaving a Central 4mm Optical Zone.
  • These incisions on Healing cause Flattening of the Corneal Curvature.

 

Education Objective:

 

Central Optional Zone in Radial Keratotomy is 4mm.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 592

questions.text: ​​​​​​​A middle-aged woman presents with dull, ocular pain, mild proptosis and decreased vision. Ultrasonography was performed, and the provided image shows characteristic “T Sign”. Based on these clinical manifestations and imaging, what is the most probable aetiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior Scleritis

 

Option A:

 

  • The given picture is of a B-scan sonogram showing T sign which is characteristic of posterior scleritis. The stem of the T being formed by the optic nerve and the cross bar by the fluid-containing gap.
  • Posterior scleritis is inflammation of sclera behind the equator
  • Ultrasonography shows increased scleral thickness and fluid in the Sub-Tenon space.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Retrobulbar hemorrhage is the accumulation of blood behind the eyeball. It can cause proptosis (bulging of the eye), but it typically does not result in a "T sign" on ultrasonography.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the tissues within the orbit. Imaging studies may reveal signs of inflammation, such as fluid accumulation or abscess formation, but it does not typically manifest as a "T sign" on ultrasound.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve. It may present with “double optic nerve” sign on ultrasound to thickening of the perineural sheath,

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "T sign" on ultrasonography is a characteristic finding seen in Posterior scleritis.

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 298

questions.text: This test is based on?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chromatic Aberration

 

  • The given test is Duo chrome test.
  • It is based on the principle of chromatic aberration.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Interference - This is a phenomenon where waves overlap, and the resulting wave amplitude is either increased (constructive interference) or decreased (destructive interference). Polarised glasses are used in tests evaluating stereopsis.

 

Option C. Prismatic effect - This occurs when light is bent as it passes through a prism. Prisms are used for evaluation and management of squint.

 

Option D. Diffraction - This involves the bending of light waves around obstacles and the spreading of light from a coherent source. Edges of IOLS are designed to reduce diffraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duo chrome test is based on the principle of chromatic aberration, which is utilized to fine-tune the refractive power needed for vision correction by comparing the focus of red and green light on the retina.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 588

questions.text: A 12-year-old female student complains of experiencing blurred vision and difficulty seeing objects in the distance. On examination, her eyes appeared normal with vision of 6/6 in both eyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudo Myopia

 

Option B: A school-going girl experiencing difficulty in seeing distant objects while having a visual acuity of 6/6 suggests a diagnosis of Pseudo myopia. It has been caused most probably due to increase in near-work like reading, writing, or using digital devices leading to overstimulation of ciliary muscle.

 

MYOPIA TYPES

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Index myopia refers to myopia caused by changes in the refractive index of the lens or other ocular media, often related to metabolic changes, and would not usually resolve to show a normal vision of 6/6 during an eye examination.

 

Option C. Simple myopia, or true myopia, is a permanent change in the eye where the eyeball is too long relative to the focusing power of the cornea and lens. This would usually result in a permanent decrease in distance vision, not intermittent symptoms.

 

Option D. Induced myopia can be caused by various factors, including medications, increased blood sugar levels, or exposure to various environmental factors. Like index myopia, it would not typically present with normal vision during an examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis for a patient experiencing blurred distance vision intermittently but showing normal vision on examination is pseudo myopia, which is often due to a transient spasm of the ciliary muscles after prolonged close work.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition Page 71

questions.text: A patient underwent prophylactic Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy. All of the following agents is prescribed to counter post procedure spike in IOP, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pilocarpine

 

Option D: Pilocarpine, a cholinergic agonist, works by constricting the pupil and pulling the iris away from the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing aqueous humor outflow. However, in the context of post-iridotomy care, pilocarpine is the exception. The purpose of an iridotomy is to create an opening in the iris to relieve pupillary block and facilitate aqueous humor flow, rendering the action of pilocarpine (which aims to achieve a similar outcome through miosis) less relevant or even counterproductive post-iridotomy. The iridotomy itself should alleviate the mechanism that pilocarpine targets, and additional constriction of the pupil may not be beneficial.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Timolol as a beta-blocker, Timolol decreases aqueous humor production, thus lowering IOP. It is commonly used in glaucoma management, including after laser procedures, to control IOP.

 

Option B. Dorzolamide, topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production. It is also used in glaucoma management and can be used post-laser procedures to control IOP spikes.

 

Option C. Apraclonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is specifically used to prevent or treat spikes in IOP after laser eye surgery, making it highly relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine is the exception, as it is less likely to be prescribed post Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy to counter a spike in IOP, given that the procedure itself addresses the issue pilocarpine is used to manage.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 157

questions.text: The most actively metabolising layers of cornea are?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epithelium & Endothelium

 

Option D: Epithelium & endothelium are the most actively metabolising layers of cornea.

 

Epithelium is 10x thicker than the latter, and requires a proportionately larger supply of metabolic substrates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epithelium & Bowman’s Layer: The epithelium is a highly active metabolic layer. However, Bowman's layer, which lies beneath the epithelium, is an acellular zone and does not engage in active metabolism.

 

Option B. Epithelium & Stroma: The stroma is the thickest layer of the cornea and contains collagen and keratocytes. While it has some metabolic activity, it is not as metabolically active as the epithelium or endothelium.

 

Option C. Epithelium & Descemet’s Membrane: Descemet's membrane is a thin, acellular layer produced by the endothelial cells. It does not have significant metabolic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epithelium and endothelium are the most actively metabolizing layers of the cornea, playing vital roles in corneal health, repair, and functionality.

 

 

Ref: pg 40/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: During an eye examination, a 40-year-old patient presented with complaints of blurred vision and difficulty reading. While performing keratometry, it was observed that the horizontal meridian exhibited a higher degree of curvature compared to the vertical meridian. Based on these findings, the likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Against the Rule Astigmatism

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. With the rule astigmatism - With the rule astigmatism is characterized by a greater curvature of the cornea in the vertical meridian than in the horizontal meridian

 

Option C. Oblique astigmatism - In this type, the steepest curve lies in an oblique axis, neither horizontal nor vertical.

 

Option D. Bioblique astigmatism - This occurs when both principal meridians are oblique and at different angles that are neither vertical nor horizontal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Against the rule astigmatism is when the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. This type of astigmatism is commonly corrected with glasses or contact lenses that have the appropriate cylindrical correction.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 36

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of itching, redness, and mucous discharge from both eyes, particularly during the spring and summer months. On examination, you observe the presence of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of immunologic reaction is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction

 

Option A: This is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE antibodies. In conditions like VKC, exposure to specific allergens triggers the IgE-mediated activation of mast cells, leading to the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. This results in symptoms such as itching, redness, and mucous discharge, which are characteristic of allergic reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Type 2 Hypersensitivity Reaction involves antibodies (IgG or IgM) directed against cell surface or tissue antigens, leading to cell damage. This mechanism is typically involved in diseases where there is a reaction against self-antigens or modified host cells, and it is not associated with VKC.

 

Option C. Type 3 Hypersensitivity Reaction involves the formation of immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that deposit in tissues and cause inflammation. Commonly seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus and serum sickness, it is not the mechanism involved in VKC.

 

Option D. Type 4 Hypersensitivity Reaction, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, this reaction is cell-mediated, primarily involving T cells. It is the mechanism behind conditions such as contact dermatitis and tuberculosis skin tests, but not VKC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms and signs of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis, such as itching, redness, mucous discharge, and giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, are indicative of a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, where IgE-mediated immune responses play a central role in the pathogenesis of the condition

 

Ref: 80/CONJUNCTIVA/Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/6th Edition

questions.text: The type of optic atrophy seen in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consecutive

 

Option C:

 

  • The fundus picture shows retinitis pigmentosa.

  • There occurs consecutive optic atrophy characterized by waxy pallor of the optic disc.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consecutive optic neuropathy is a form of optic nerve damage resulting as a consequence of pathologies of retina and uvea. It is characterized by progressive axonal loss leading to optic atrophy, visual impairment, and optic disc pallor on examination. Management focuses on treating the underlying cause and supporting vision with aids if necessary.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 753

questions.text: A middle-aged male presented to the OPD with a head tilt to the left side. On examination, it is observed that he has right hypertropia which increases on levoversion and left head-tilt. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left superior rectus

 

Explanation:

 

In this question, the patient presenting with left head tilt is the compensatory head position to avoid diplopia. Analysis of paretic muscle is done in primary position. Student must not get confused between head tilt at presentation and the head tilt in which the hypertropia is more.

 

  • Head tilt is a form of compensatory head posture to avoid diplopia.

  • In case of 4th nerve palsy – head tilt is towards the opposite side.

  • PARK THREE STEP TEST – allows to identify the muscle involved in patients with vertical diplopia.

 

 

The student must not try to learn the outcomes of this table. While analysing any question on Park 3 step test, it is better to draw the following diagram:

 

 

Step 1: which eye is hypertropic: The elevators of the contralateral eye are paretic or depressors of ipsilateral eye are paretic. So in this case, it is right hypertropia. Thus, contralateral LSR or  LIO or ipsilateral RSO or RIR. 

 

Step 2: Which Gaze: Draw a circle around the muscles on that side of the diagram, the gaze in which the hypertropia is more. So in this case, it is more on left gaze, thus, LSR or RSO

 

Step 3: Which head tilt: Draw a diagonal line – upper side of the line starts from the upper corner of the direction of head tilt. So in this case, left head tilt, Thus the correct answer would be LSR. 

 

Interpretation: The muscle which lies in the interjection of all the 3 steps, is the paretic muscle.

 

Other example for practice in which hypertropia is more with right head tilt. The answer changes to Left Inferior Oblique.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the concept behind Park Three step test is crucial. Step-wise approach to such questions are necessary to solve them.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 826-827

choices.text: Single Layer of Epithelial Cells

questions.text: A 65-year-old man came to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of gradually increasing blurring of vision in both his eyes since 1 year. After examination, he was diagnosed with bilateral mature senile cataract and was explained how his lenses had lost their transparency leading to blurring of vision. Factors that play significant role in maintaining the outstanding clarity of normal lens are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vascularity

 

Option C: Causes of Lens Transparency:

 

  • Single layer of epithelial cells
  • Tightly packed lens proteins
  • Pump mechanism
  • Avascularity
  • Auto oxidation of glutathione

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lens is covered by a single layer of epithelial cells on its anterior surface. These cells are essential for lens growth and transparency. They help regulate water and ion balance in the lens and produce lens fibers, which are crucial for maintaining lens clarity.

 

Option B. Lens has natural auto oxidation mechanism.

 

Option D. The lens contains ion channels and pumps that help maintain its dehydration and precise ion balance, which are essential for lens transparency. Disruption in this pump mechanism can lead to cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lens is an avascular structure, meaning it lacks blood vessels. This avascularity is crucial for its transparency. If the lens were vascularized, the blood vessels would interfere with light transmission and clarity.

 

Ref: 127/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd Edition

questions.text: What is the total dioptric power in a Donders’ reduced eye model?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) + 60D

 

Option B: The concept of reduced eye: Instead of the eye being a combination of multiple refracting surfaces (cornea, aqueous humor, lens, vitreous humor), it is imagined as a single, ideal spherical refracting surface to understand the focusing mechanism of the eye as an optical device.

 

PARAMETERS IN DONDER’S REDUCED EYE MODEL

 

  • Principal Point – 1.5mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Nodal Point – 7.2mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Anterior Focal Point – 15.7mm in front of anterior surface of cornea
  • Posterior Focal Point – 24.23mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Total Dioptric Power +60D (+43D cornea and +17D lens)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. +58.64D: This value is close to the actual combined dioptric power of the human eye, but it's slightly less than the standard value used for the reduced eye model.

 

Option C. +43D: This value is the power of the cornea in the reduced eye model.

 

Option D. +53D: This is also lower than the typical total dioptric power of the human eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total dioptric power of the reduced eye, a simplified model of the human eye, is conventionally set at +60 diopters, encompassing the combined refractive powers of the cornea and the lens.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 26

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female presents to the emergency department with redness, purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling in the left eye. On further evaluation, the diagnosis of gonococcal conjunctivitis is confirmed. Which of the following complications is the patient at the highest risk for if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans: A) Corneal Ulceration:

 

Option A: Corneal Ulceration: Untreated gonococcal conjunctivitis can lead to severe corneal involvement, including corneal ulceration. This complication results from the direct invasion of Neisseria gonorrhoeae into the cornea and can cause significant vision impairment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cataract Formation: While cataract formation is a potential complication of ocular infections, it is not the primary concern in gonococcal conjunctivitis. Corneal involvement and subsequent complications are more common in this condition.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is not typically associated with gonococcal conjunctivitis. It occurs due to the separation of the retina from the underlying tissue and is not a common sequela of this type of conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Optic Neuritis: Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve and can lead to vision impairment. It is not a direct complication of gonococcal conjunctivitis. Complications in gonococcal conjunctivitis usually involve the anterior segment of the eye, such as the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient with gonococcal conjunctivitis is at the highest risk for the complication of Corneal ulceration. This complication can result in significant vision loss and highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of gonococcal conjunctivitis to prevent severe ocular damage.

 

Ref: Pg 64/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

 

Option D.

 

  • The picture shows right homonymous hemianopia.

  • Site of lesion – left optic tract.

  • This is associated with Wernicke’s pupil.

 

 

 

Wernicke Pupil

 

When the optic chiasm is bisected sagittally, the nasal halves of each retina become insensitive to light so that there is not only a bitemporal hemianopia but also a bitemporal pupillary hemiakinesia; that is, light falling on the nasal retina of either eye will fail to produce a pupillary constriction. Thus, if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation. It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil, it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil. It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.

 

Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction. It is detected using the swinging flashlight test. However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of right homonymous hemianopia, the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract, and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 312

2. Walsh and Hoyt’s Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology 6th Edition pg. No: 747

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to an ophthalmologist with occasional headaches and no specific vision complaints. The examination reveals increased cupping of the optic disc, visual field defects, and elevated intraocular pressure. A diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma is made. Treatment is initiated with topical eye drops and regular follow-up visits are scheduled. The following finding is noticed on a follow-up visit. Which drug(s) is/are responsible for it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Latanoprost

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows Long, Thick Eyelashes which is a side-effect of Prostaglandin analogues.

 

Prostaglandin Analogues:

 

  • Latanoprost
  • Travoprost
  • Bimatoprost
  • Tafluprost

 

Side effects of Prostaglandin Analogues

 

  1. Conjunctival Hyperemia
  2. Eyelash Lengthening, Thickening, Hyperpigmentation
  3. Irreversible Iris Hyperpigmentation
  4. Reversible Hyperpigmentation of Periocular Skin
  5. Increased risk of Cystoid Macular Edema following Cataract Surgery

 

Educational objective:

 

A well-documented side effect of Prostaglandin Analogs, including Latanoprost, is increased Eyelash Growth, or Hypertrichosis.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 331

questions.text: All of the following are features of trachoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobblestone Papillae

 

Option B.

 

Cobblestone papillae are seen in VKC.

 

  • Features of trachoma include:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herbert Pits are small, shallow depressions found on the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera) in the advanced stages of trachoma. They are the result of resolved limbal follicles and are a characteristic sign of chronic or healed trachoma. This feature is indeed associated with trachoma.

 

Option C. Artl’s Line is a scar line seen in the sulcus subtarsalis in the upper eyelid in chronic trachoma. It is formed due to the healing of conjunctival scarring and is a sign of advanced disease. This feature is a part of trachoma's presentation.

 

Option D. Trichiasis refers to the inward turning of the eyelashes, which rub against the cornea and conjunctiva, causing irritation and potential corneal damage. Trichiasis is a common complication of chronic trachoma due to scarring of the eyelid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cobblestone papillae are not a feature of Trachoma.

 

Ref: Pg 68/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

choices.text: Infraorbital nerve anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

 

Option A:

 

A blow out fracture of the orbital floor is caused by sudden increase in orbital pressure due to trauma.

 

Signs:

 

  • Enophthalmos - due to displacement of intraorbital contents
  • Diplopia – due to extra ocular muscle entrapment in fracture
  • Infra orbital anesthesia - if fracture involves infra orbital canal through which infra orbital nerve passes.
  • Others - periorbital edema, ecchymosis, subcutaneous emphysema, etc

 

PlainX-Ray- Water’s view is the best.

 

Most common wall of the orbit to be fractured in blow-out fractures is the floor.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diplopia: It is a common symptom of blow-out fractures, often resulting from impaired movement of the affected eye due to muscle entrapment or nerve damage.

 

Option C. Enophthalmos: This is the posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. It is a characteristic sign of blow-out fractures. The increase in the orbital volume caused by the fracture allows the eyeball to sink backward.

 

Option D. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia: This refers to a loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, typically the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip. It can occur in blow-out fractures if the fracture involves the infraorbital groove or canal, where the nerve runs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos, is a sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit. Blow-out fractures typically increase orbital volume, allowing the eyeball to sink backward, leading to enophthalmos, rather than protruding forward as in exophthalmos.

 

Ref: pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

 

Option C:

 

This condition, characterized by a difference in color between the two irises, is not typically a feature of adult-onset Horner's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with congenital Horner's syndrome, where the condition is present from birth or early childhood.

 

Causes of HORNER’S SYNDROME:

 

  • Ptosis

  • Miosis

  • Heterochromia iridis

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.

 

Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face. It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.

 

Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.

 

Conclusion:

 

Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.

 

Ref: pg344/anatomy & physiology of eye 3rd edition – ak Khurana (pg 575)

questions.text: A patient present with proptosis, vision changes, and eye pain. After thorough examination and imaging, the ophthalmologist makes the diagnosis of an orbital tumour. Which is the most common benign orbital tumour in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cavernous haemangioma

 

Option B:

 

Cavernous hemangiomas are the most common primary benign orbital tumors in adults. They are slow-growing vascular lesions that can cause proptosis and visual changes due to their size and location.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rhabdomyosarcoma: This is a type of malignant tumor that arises from skeletal muscle. It is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children, not adults.

 

Option C. Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma: This represents a group of blood cancers that develop in the lymphatic system. While it can involve the orbit, it is not classified as a benign tumor. Orbital involvement in non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma usually indicates a systemic disease rather than a primary orbital tumor.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: This is a malignant tumor that arises from nerve tissue. It is most commonly seen in children and is not a benign tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common benign orbital tumor in adults is a cavernous hemangioma.

 

Ref: pg 102/orbit/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of 5 days of progressive left facial swelling and fever. On ocular inspection, left periorbital oedema, erythema and discharge are noted. On examination, left eye showed decrease in visual acuity, and the pupil showed relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

 

Option B:

 

Orbital cellulitis-

 

  • Fever, chills

  • Periorbital edema, erythema, extra ocular movement restriction

  • Optic nerve involvement- decreased vision, RAPD

  • If progresses- intra orbital abscess.

 

Other choices: Usually don’t present with fever, chills, erythema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation): This is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins, bypassing the capillary system. It can cause swelling and other issues due to altered blood flow, but it typically does not present with infection-like symptoms (fever, discharge) or a rapid onset of visual changes and RAPD.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: A malignant tumor of the retina, common in children. It usually presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may cause vision loss. However, retinoblastoma does not typically cause fever, periorbital edema, or erythema, which are indicative of an infectious process.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: A cancer that develops from immature nerve cells, mostly occurring in children. It can present with various symptoms depending on the site of the tumor but is unlikely to cause localized periorbital edema, erythema, and discharge without other systemic or neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pediatric patient presenting with fever, progressive facial swelling, periorbital edema, erythema, discharge, decreased visual acuity, and RAPD, the most probable diagnosis is Orbital Cellulitis, an infectious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the orbital tissues, often requiring prompt medical intervention.

 

Ref: pg 409/ orbit/ 6th edition comprehensive ophthalmology  ak khurana

choices.text: Ice pack test
Snap back test

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman with a history of right eye ptosis for 6 months, the eyelids appear asymmetrical, and the ptosis fluctuates throughout the day, worsening in the evening. The fatigability test shows positive results. Which of the following tests is not helpful in diagnosing the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Snap back test

 

Option C:

 

Snap back test is used for ectropion, to check lower lid laxity.

 

The following signs and symptoms given in the question are suggestive of Myasthenic ptosis:

 

  • Unilateral
  • Asymmetrical
  • Diurnal variation
  • Fatigability present

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Edrophonium Test: This test is useful in diagnosing MG. Edrophonium, a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to an improvement in muscle strength in patients with MG.

 

Option B. Ice Pack Test: This test is also helpful in MG. Cooling improves neuromuscular transmission, and thus, application of an ice pack on the eyelids can temporarily improve ptosis in MG.

 

Option D. Electromyography (EMG): EMG, especially single-fiber EMG, is a key diagnostic tool in MG. It measures the electrical activity of muscles and can detect the characteristic patterns of neuromuscular transmission failure seen in MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the evaluation of a patient with fluctuating ptosis and positive fatigability, suggesting Myasthenia Gravis, the Snap Back Test is not useful as it assesses eyelid laxity rather than neuromuscular strength or transmission, which are the key pathological features in Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Ref: pg 838/ neuro ophthalmology/ kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient who is on ATT came to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision and impairment in colour vision. On carrying out perimetry, bilateral centrocecal scotoma is noted. Which of the following drug may be responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Option C:

 

  • The scenario given above is suggestive of toxic optic neuropathy.
  • Red–green dyschromatopsia is the most common objective abnormality of colour vision, but subtle (undetectable on Ishihara testing) blue–yellow defects may be an early finding.
  • Visual loss occurs due to damage to optic nerve fibres as a result of exogenous toxins.
  • These include
    • Tobacco 
    • Ethyl alcohol
    • Methyl alcohol
    • Quinine
    • Ethambutol
  • In most cases of ethambutol induced optic neuropathy, resolution occurs following cessation of the drug.
  • Before starting the drug, visual acuity and colour vision is to be tested, and followed up every 6 months after starting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyrazinamide: This drug is not commonly associated with ocular side effects. It is more known for its hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause various side effects, including liver dysfunction and hypersensitivity reactions, but it is not typically associated with the specific ocular side effects described in the question.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside, is more commonly associated with vestibular and auditory side effects, such as vertigo and hearing loss, rather than with ocular side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an antituberculosis drug, can cause optic neuropathy leading to blurring of vision, impaired color vision, and centrocecal scotoma. This is a critical side effect to monitor for in patients on antituberculosis regimens including ethambutol.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 316

questions.text: When light is flashed onto one eye, both the eyes’ pupils constrict as a response. This is known as the pupillary light reflex. Where is the center for this reflex located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Midbrain

 

Option B:

 

  • The pupillary reflex fibres are relayed to the PRETECTAL NUCLEUS located in the midbrain.
  • Afferent: Optic Nerve
  • Efferent: Short ciliary nerves

 

 

Midbrain: The midbrain plays a crucial role in the control of eye movements, primarily through two key structures: the superior colliculi and the oculomotor nerve nuclei (cranial nerve III).

 

  1. Superior Colliculi:
    • The superior colliculi, located in the tectum of the midbrain, are involved in the initiation of saccadic eye movements. These are rapid, jerky movements of the eyes that abruptly change the point of fixation.
    • They receive visual inputs as well as inputs from other sensory modalities and are responsible for directing the eyes toward an object of interest, particularly in response to new or sudden visual stimuli.
  2. Oculomotor Nerve Nuclei:
    • The oculomotor nerve nuclei control most of the eye's movements and are responsible for the constriction of the pupil and maintaining an open eyelid.
    • They coordinate the actions of the muscles that control the movement of the eyeball and the upper eyelid. Specifically, they innervate the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, the inferior oblique muscle, the levator palpebrae superioris, and the sphincter pupillae.

 

Additionally, the midbrain is involved in the integration of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), which stabilizes the visual field during head movements, and the accommodation reflex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pons: Pontine centres are involved in optokinetic nystagmus. Pontine lesions cause dolls eye movement.

 

Option D: Cerebellum- Cerebellum is involved in integration and coordination of optokinetic nystagmus. Characteristics of cerebellar nystagmus include:

 

  1. Direction: It is typically horizontal, but can also be vertical or rotary. The direction of the nystagmus may change depending on the direction of gaze.
  2. Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus: This form of nystagmus becomes more pronounced when the patient looks to the side. It is due to the failure of the cerebellum to hold steady gaze, leading to a drift of the eyes back to the central position, followed by a corrective saccade.
  3. Intensity and Amplitude: The intensity and amplitude of the nystagmus can increase with the degree of lateral gaze and decrease or disappear with gaze towards the midline.
  4. Associated Symptoms: Patients with cerebellar nystagmus may also exhibit other signs of cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia, dysarthria, and tremor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the pupillary light reflex is mediated by the midbrain, involving an interplay between the optic and oculomotor nerves.

 

REF: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PAGE 33

questions.text: In the lens, what is/are the pathway(s) involved in the metabolism of glucose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D: Glucose Metabolism in the lens:

 

  1. Anaerobic Glycolysis
  2. Kerb’s Cycle
  3. HMP Pathway
  4. Sorbitol Pathway

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle) is a key metabolic pathway that generates energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. However, in the lens, the Krebs cycle plays a minimal role because the lens operates in a relatively hypoxic environment and relies more on anaerobic glycolysis for its energy requirements.

 

Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway), also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is an important metabolic pathway in the lens. It provides the lens with NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining reduced glutathione levels. Reduced glutathione is vital for protecting the lens against oxidative stress, thus helping maintain its transparency and preventing cataract formation.

 

Option C. Sorbitol Pathway, also known as the polyol pathway, involves the conversion of glucose to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. In the lens, this pathway becomes particularly active in hyperglycemic conditions, such as in diabetes, and can lead to the accumulation of sorbitol. Excessive accumulation of sorbitol can cause osmotic stress, leading to lens swelling, opacification, and cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose metabolism in the lens is through Krebs cycle, HMP pathway and Sorbitol pathway.

 

Ref: Pg 123/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which enzyme is implicated in Classic Galactosaemic, an inborn error of Galactose Metabolism that leads to the development of Cataracts in Infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GALPUT (Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyltransferase)

 

Option A:

 

  • In classic galactosemia, there is deficiency of GALPUT (Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyltransferase).

 

 

  • Absence of GALPUT leads to accumulation of galactose and other toxic substances (such as galactitol) which leads to accumulation of water and leads to cataract (‘Oil-drop cataract’).
  • Cataract may be prevented if milk & milk products are eliminated from the diet.
  • Symptoms (Failure to Thrive, Jaundice, Hepatomegaly, Infantile Cataracts) develop when infant begins feeding (Lactose present in Breast Milk and formula feed).
  • Can predispose to E.coli sepsis in neonates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Galactokinase deficiency is another form of galactosemia, known as galactokinase deficiency galactosemia.

 

Option C. Aldose Reductase is involved in the polyol pathway, where it reduces glucose to sorbitol. While important in the context of diabetes-related cataract formation, it is not the enzyme implicated in classic galactosemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GALPUT (Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase) Deficiency leads to classic Galactosemia, which is associated with the development of cataracts in infants.

 

Ref: Pg 134/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Absence of which of the following enzymes in the sorbitol pathway leads to accumulation of excess sugar?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sorbitol Dehydrogenase 

 

 

 

Fig: Polyol (Sorbitol) pathway

 

  • Aldose Reductase is the sorbitol pathway enzyme which converts the excess sugar in the lens to the corresponding sugar alcohol. Thus, if it is deficient, there is an accumulation of sugar (glucose).
  • The deficiency of Sorbitol dehydrogenase causes intracellular accumulation of sorbitol leading to osmotic changes resulting in hydropic lens fibers that degenerate and form sugar cataracts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hexokinase catalyzes the first step in glycolysis, the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. While it's important in glucose metabolism, it is not directly involved in the sorbitol pathway. Hexokinase deficiency would affect glycolysis but not specifically lead to the accumulation of excess sugar in the sorbitol pathway.

 

Option C. Aldose Reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol, the first step in the sorbitol pathway. However, a deficiency in aldose reductase would actually lead to less sorbitol being produced from glucose, not more.

 

Option D.Galactokinase is involved in galactose metabolism, not the sorbitol pathway. It catalyzes the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. Galactokinase deficiency leads to a different type of galactosemia but would not directly cause the accumulation of sorbitol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence or deficiency of Sorbitol Dehydrogenase in the sorbitol pathway leads to the accumulation of sorbitol, as it cannot be efficiently converted to fructose, leading to osmotic stress in cells and formation of cataract.

 

Ref:  Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What can be prevented by inhibiting Aldol Reductase in Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic Cataract

 

Option A:

  • Aldose reductase is the sorbitol pathway enzyme which converts the excess sugar in the lens to the corresponding sugar alcohol.
  • The intracellular accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic changes resulting in hydropic lens fibres that degenerate and form sugar cataracts.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While diabetic nephropathy is a major complication of diabetes, the role of aldose reductase in its development is less direct compared to its role in cataracts.

 

Option C. Diabetic Neuropathy is also a complication where aldose reductase plays a role. Increased activity of the polyol pathway in nerve cells can lead to osmotic and oxidative stress, contributing to nerve damage. Inhibiting aldose reductase can therefore potentially help in preventing or slowing the progression of diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option D. Deafness: While diabetes can lead to a range of complications, there is no direct evidence linking aldose reductase activity to diabetes-related deafness. Deafness in diabetic patients is more commonly associated with other factors such as microvascular complications and neuropathies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most direct and well-established effect of inhibiting aldose reductase in the context of diabetes is the prevention of Diabetic Cataract

 

Ref:  Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Hypermetropia

 

Option C:

 

  • The clinical signs – a jet black pupil, and presence of only two Purkinje images - point towards aphakia.
  • Total power of the eye is reduced from +60D to about +44D – hence eye becomes highly hypermetropic.
  • On performing retinoscopy on a hypermetropic/emmetropic/ myopic eye with power <1D: the red reflex is along movement.
  • To correct high hypermetropia, high power plus lenses are used.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Low Hypermetropia: Hypermetropia (farsightedness) occurs when the eye is too short or the lens is too weak, causing light to focus behind the retina. However, the absence of the lens in aphakia leads to a much more significant refractive error than what would be classified as "low" hypermetropia.

 

Option B. Low Myopia: Myopia (near-sightedness) is when the eye is too long or the lens is too strong, causing light to focus in front of the retina. Aphakia does not typically result in myopia, as the removal of the lens significantly reduces the eye's refractive power.

 

Option D. High Myopia: As mentioned, aphakia generally does not lead to myopia. The condition results in a loss of refractive power, not an excess of it, which would be necessary to cause high myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In aphakic patients, where the natural lens of the eye is absent, retinoscopy typically reveals high hypermetropia due to the significant reduction in the eye's refractive power.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 31

choices.text: Retrieve and store donor eyes
Evaluate and distribute eye tissue for transplantation
Use donor eyes for research and education

questions.text: What is the function of an Eye Bank?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

  • Promotion of eye donation.

  • Registration & collection of donated eyes.

  • Receiving & preservation of donor eyes.

  • Distribution & research activities.

 

Ref: pg 487/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

choices.text: Eyes can be removed from a living human being with consent.
Optic atrophy in recipient is a contraindication
Donated eyes can never be sold or bought.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding eye donation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eyes can be removed from a living human being with consent.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anyone of any age can pledge to donate eyes after death.

  • Donated eyes can never be bought or sold.

  • Eyes CANNOT be removed from a living human being inspite of his/her consent & wish.

  • Contraindications for eye donation include transmissible diseases like – HIV, HBsAg, syphilis, TB etc.

  • Recipients with only anterior segment diseases are eligible for corneal transplantation, and should have a normal posterior segment.

questions.text: What is the sample used for the screening of HIV, Syphilis, HBsAg and Anti-HCV in an eye donor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the time of eye retrieval , blood sample is collected from the cadaver and sent for screening infections like- HIV, HBsAg, Syphilis etc.

 

Ref: Pg 560/ Eye banking/ PEYMAN’S principle & practise of ophthalmology/ 2nd edition

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of short-term storage after eye ball retrieval?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moist chamber storage

 

Option B.

 

Whole globe is sealed in a container and stored at 4 degree C.

 

Short-term (upto 48 hours) = Moist chamber storage

 

 

Intermediate (2 weeks) = MK medium, optisol

 

Long-term (35 days) = Organ culture method, cryopreservation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MK Medium (McCarey-Kaufman Medium): This is a medium used for the storage of corneal tissues. However, MK medium is typically used for short-term preservation of up to 4 days. It's often used in scenarios where corneal transplantation is planned shortly after retrieval.

 

 

Option C. Cryopreservation: This method involves freezing the tissue for long-term storage. Cryopreservation is not commonly used for corneal storage due to the risk of damaging the corneal endothelial cells during the freeze-thaw process.

 

Option D. Organ Culture Method: This is a method used for longer-term storage of corneal tissues, allowing storage for up to 4 weeks. It involves keeping the cornea in a special nutrient medium at a controlled temperature, which is higher than that used in MK medium or moist chamber storage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Moist chamber storage is a method used for the short-term storage of corneal tissue after eyeball retrieval, suitable for maintaining the viability of the cornea for up to 24-48 hours.

 

Ref: pg 137/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: When was NPCB established in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1976

 

Explanation

 

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) was launched in India in 1976 with the goal of reducing the prevalence of blindness through comprehensive eye care services and improving accessibility to eye care facilities across the country. This program has been pivotal in addressing various eye-related issues and enhancing the quality of life for many individuals.

 

Key aspects of the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) include:

 

  1. Focus on Preventable Blindness: A significant emphasis is placed on preventing blindness caused by conditions that are easily treatable, such as cataract, which is the leading cause of blindness in India.
  2. Community Participation: The program encourages community involvement and utilizes a decentralized approach, engaging primary health centers and local healthcare workers to maximize its outreach and impact.
  3. Capacity Building: It aims to strengthen the infrastructure for eye care services by upgrading existing facilities, providing training to eye care professionals, and increasing the availability of specialized equipment and materials.
  4. Partnerships: The NPCB collaborates with various governmental and non-governmental organizations, including international agencies, to pool resources, share expertise, and expand its reach and effectiveness.
  5. Monitoring and Evaluation: Regular monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are in place to assess the program's performance, identify areas for improvement, and ensure the achievement of its targets.

 

Ref: Pg 480/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of blindness according to NPCB?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cataract

 

Cataract continues to be the single largest cause of blindness in india.

 

Main causes of blindness:

 

  • Cataract (62.6%)
  • Refractive Error (19.70%)
  • Corneal Blindness (0.90%)
  • Glaucoma (5.80%)
  • Surgical Complication (1.20%)
  • Posterior Capsular Opacification (0.90%)
  • Posterior Segment Disorder (4.70%)
  • Others (4.19%)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cataract is the commonest cause of blindness in India according to NPCB.

 

Ref: pg 483/  systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Match the following :
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-3, b-1, c-4, d-2

 

Explanation

 

 

Ref: 476/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: The following are the major blinding eye conditions for immediate attention to achieve the goals of VISION 2020, by WHO, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glaucoma

 

WHO identified 5 major blinding eye condition for immediate action:

 

  • Cataract
  • Childhood blindness
  • Trachoma
  • Refractive errors
  • Oncocerchiasis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glaucoma is not one of the primary goals of Vision 2020 initiative.

 

Ref: pg 478/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

Pizzarello L, Abiose A, Ffytche T, et al. VISION 2020: The Right to Sight: A Global Initiative to Eliminate Avoidable Blindness. Arch Ophthalmol. 2004;122(4):615–620. doi:10.1001/archopht.122.4.615

questions.text: Annually, when is the eye donation fortnight organised?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) August 25 to September 8

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under NPCB, eye donation fortnight is organised from 25th August to 8th September every year to promote eye donation.

 

Ref: pg 485/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

choices.text: Presently SICS & phacoemulsification techniques are recommended
At least 5 operating surgeons should be present
Both the eyes should never be operated at one go
Cases with surgical risks such as diabetes, hypertensives & cardiac problems should not be operated in camps

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the guidelines laid down by the government of India for organising eye camps?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) At least 5 operating surgeons should be present

 

Option B.

 

  • At least 1, preferably 2 operating surgeons should perform cataract surgeries.

  • Presently both SICS & PHACOEMULSIFICATION techniques are performed.

  • Both eyes should never be operated at one go.

  • Cases with associated risk factors should be referred to base hospitals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presently SICS & Phacoemulsification Techniques are Recommended: Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) and Phacoemulsification are modern and efficient techniques for cataract surgery. These methods are indeed recommended for their safety, effectiveness, and relatively quick recovery times.

 

Option C. Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go: This is a standard guideline in eye care, especially in camp settings. Operating on both eyes simultaneously increases the risk of complications, including infection. Therefore, it is recommended to operate on one eye at a time.

 

Option D. Cases with Surgical Risks Such as Diabetes, Hypertensives & Cardiac Problems Should Not be Operated in Camps: This statement is generally true. Patients with systemic conditions like diabetes, hypertension, or cardiac problems are at a higher risk of complications during and after surgery. Such cases typically require more comprehensive pre-operative and post-operative care than what might be available at an eye camp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the requirement of having at least 5 operating surgeons at eye camps is not a standardized guideline by the Government of India, unlike the recommendations for SICS & Phacoemulsification techniques, the practice of not operating on both eyes simultaneously, and the avoidance of operating on high-risk patients in camp settings.

 

Ref: pg 487/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Anita, a 32-year-old female patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of persistent tearing since several months and occasional eye discharge in her left eye. She notices that her left eye frequently waters, especially when she is outdoors or exposed to windy conditions. She has no history of eye trauma or previous eye surgeries. The ophthalmologist suspects a nasolacrimal duct obstruction in the left eye. What is the normal length of the duct involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 to 18 mm

 

Option C:

 

  • Nasolacrimal duct drains the tears by extending downwards from the lacrimal sac and opening into the inferior meatus of the nose which is guarded by Valve of Hasner to prevent reflux.

  • Length= 18mm (12 to 24mm)

  • Diameter = 3mm

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 5 to 10 mm: This length is of the body of the lacrimal sac.

 

Option B. 20 to 25 mm: This is the length of the inferior meatus.

 

Option D. 1 to 2 mm: This is the length of the vertical part of the canaliculus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity, is approximately 12 to 18 mm

 

Ref: pg 459/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA
